awd_titl_txt: Enrichments of Trans-Iron Elements in Planetary Nebulae: Probing Stellar Evolution and Nucleosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
The atoms in our bodies, apart from hydrogen, were produced by nuclear reactions deep within stars that lived and died before our Solar System was born.  The investigators will study the production of these chemical elements by stars like our Sun.  When our Sun reaches an age of about 10 billion years, it will expand to become a red giant star.  Such red giant stars later throw off material and form expanding, glowing clouds called planetary nebulae.  Astronomers observe the light coming from these nebulae to study their chemical properties.  The new, star-made elements flow into space and spread throughout our Milky Way Galaxy.

This project lies at the crossroads of several scientific disciplines and motivates students over a range of educational levels to enter STEM fields, which addresses an important national need.  The question "Where did the elements come from?" has broad appeal.  The project will support a graduate student at the University of Texas (UT) and undergraduates at both UT and the University of West Georgia, which have substantial populations of underrepresented minorities (Hispanic and African-American respectively).  Through teacher workshops the investigators will reach large numbers of high school students.  Pure astronomical research has strong connections to other areas of physics.  For example, some of the investigators' newly detected emission lines (e.g., rubidium, cadmium, and tellurium) were found at different energies than predicted, improving our understanding of atoms found on the Earth. 

The investigators' primary research method is near infrared and optical spectroscopy at high spectral resolution (R > 40,000) to optimize detection of weak emission lines and avoid blends with other elements.  They use standard procedures of nebular abundance analysis to derive ionic and elemental abundances from line flux measurements but incorporate new atomic models.  The goals are to distinguish which evolutionary models are most realistic and to empirically establish the contributions of 1-8 solar mass stars to Galactic chemical evolution.  The chemical yield of this numerous class of stars is a key ingredient for galactic archeology and inferring the star-forming history of the Milky Way Galaxy.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This program used infrared spectroscopy to analyze the light from a class of astronomical objects called planetary nebulae and uncover new aspects of their chemical composition.  A planetary nebula is a glowing gaseous ring around an aging star, composed of the formerly outer layers of that star that have been expelled into space and are currently illuminated by the remnant hot stellar core. This is the fate of stars those that begin their lives with up to a few times the mass of the Sun. In earlier life stages, the nuclear ovens in the centers of those stars performed alchemy by transforming atoms of light elements into heavier elements. In some cases, reactions in the very late life stages of these stars produced elements heavier than iron, by adding neutrons to nuclei and allowing radioactivity to advance them to the next element in the Periodic Table. Such was the origin of about half the trans-iron atoms in our Solar System. 

 We used state-of-the-art instruments on ground-based telescopes to study portions of the electromagnetic spectrum with wavelengths from twice to ten times that of blue light, at high magnifications of the wavelength scale. This enabled us to discover nearly a dozen weak spectroscopic signatures of rare trans-iron elements such as Br (bromine), Rb (rubidium), Cd (cadmium), and Te (tellurium), in most cases for the first time in any astronomical object. By applying calculations of relevant physical processes, we inferred the amount of each element synthesized by the planetary nebula's parent star and donated to the gas that fills interstellar space, where they are incorporated into future stars and planets. Different nebulae display different amounts of these elements relative to hydrogen, ranging from the value with which the star formed, to enrichments of as much as a factor of ten or more. On one hand, these results can be compared with theoretical calculations of heavy-element production in stars of different starting mass and composition, to better understand the life stories of stars. On the other hand, they indirectly tell us how many stars with these properties lived and died before the formation of younger stars, providing empirical information essential for unraveling the nuclear history of our Galaxy, an area of study called "galactic archeology." Our results have been disseminated through publications in professional journals and presentations at topical conferences.

 Another aspect of the program was to sponsor two 3-day workshops for in-service middle and high school science teachers, held at the site of McDonald Observatory (operated by the University of Texas at Austin) during the summers of 2018 and 2019. The grant supported most of the expenses of the roughly two dozen teacher-participants. The P.I. co-led these workshops in person together with astronomy educators and staff members of the Observatory's Frank N. Bash Visitors Center, a popular tourist site in west Texas featuring museum-type exhibits, public viewing, and educational outreach programs. The teacher-participants experienced tutorials on basic aspects of astronomy, spectroscopy, and life histories of stars, as well as night-time telescope viewings. They acted out examples of demonstrations and participatory exercises suitable for use in their own classrooms, and mingled informally with astronomers in the observatory dormitory. As documented through end-of-workshop assessments, the participants found their experience greatly enjoyable and useful. These workshops have a large multiplier effect, since each teacher interacts with hundreds of young students every year.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2023
Modified by: Harriet Dinerstein
